etymology: From French ‘prestigieux’, from Latin ‘praestīgium’ (illusion, trick). Sense ‘highly respected’ developed later.
From French ‘questionnaire’ (list of questions), ultimately from Latin ‘quaestiō’ (inquiry).
From Greek ‘psukhē’ (mind/soul) + ‘-iatrist’ from ‘iatreia’ (healing). Practitioner of psychiatry.
From Latin ‘perseverantia’ via Old French. From ‘per-’ (thoroughly) + ‘severus’ (strict) → ‘persist’.
From Latin ‘accommodāre’ (to make fit), with double m and double d → English ‘accommodate’.
From Latin ‘relevare’ (to lighten, raise again), via Medieval Latin ‘relevans’ → French → English.
From Latin ‘suscipere’ (to take up), influenced by ‘susceptibilis’ (capable of receiving).
From Latin ‘vertere’ (to turn). Sense of dizziness from a feeling of turning.
From Greek ‘turannos’ (tyrant) via Latin and Old French.
From phrase ‘in devoir’ (in duty) Middle English; later merged as ‘endeavour/endeavor’.
Probably from Old French ‘gorgias’ (elegant), related to ‘gorge’ (throat/neck, decorated).
